topic.title: HPE Helion OpenStack 1.1: Community How To's with the Compute Service

body.p: Leveraging OpenStack Compute, the HPE Helion OpenStack Community Compute provides a way to instantiate virtual servers on publicly accessible physical machines hosted in HPE data centers.
The following lists of tasks can be performed by a user or administrator through the HPE Helion OpenStack Community Dashboard, the OpenStack CLI or OpenStack API.
For details on performing these tasks using the API or CLI, see the following OpenStack documentation:
Depending upon your user type,user or administrator, you can perform the following tasks.

section.title: Tasks performed by users
section.p: The following Compute service tasks are usually performed by someone with the user role.

section.title: Working with a virtual machine
section.p: When working with the Compute service, you can perform a number of tasks with your virtual machines (VM), including creating and deleting VMs, starting and stopping a VM, and attaching the VM to a storage volume.

section.title: Launching a virtual machine
section.p: Use the Compute service to create a new virtual machine.

ol.li: Launch the HPE Helion OpenStack interface.
On the Project dashboard, click Compute > Instance.

section.title: Launching a virtual machine that boots from a Volume
section.p: Use the Compute service to create a bootable virtual machine associated with a bootable volume.

section.title: Rebooting a virtual machine
section.p: Use the Compute service to reboot a virtual machine, as needed

section.title: Rebuilding a virtual machine
section.p: Use the Compute service to rebuild a virtual machine as needed.

section.title: Starting and stopping a virtual machine
section.p: Use the Compute service to start and stop a virtual machine.

section.title: Creating and deleting a snapshot of a virtual machine
section.p: Use the Compute service to create a snapshot of a virtual machine that you can use to create other VMs

section.title: Rescuing and un-rescuing a virtual machine
section.p: Use the Compute service to resuce a VM.

section.title: Deleting a virtual machine
section.p: Use the Compute service to delete a virtual machine that is no longer needed.

section.title: Attaching and detaching volumes
section.p: Use the Compute service to attach a storage volume to a virtual machine and detach the volume, when no longer needed.

section.title: Viewing a virtual machine console log
section.p: Use the Compute service to display a log of virtual machine activity.

section.title: Viewing a VNC console connection to a virtual machine
section.p: Use the Compute service to remotely connect to a virtual machine using a VNC (Virtual Network Computing) console.

section.title: Associating and disassociating a floating IP address
section.p: Use the Compute service to allocate and associate floating IP addresses for a virtual machine.

section.title: Working with security groups
section.p: Use the Compute service to create, modify, and delete the security groups in your project.

section.title: Working with key pairs
section.p: Use the Compute service to create and delete the key pairs that control access to the virtual machines in your environment.

section.title: Creating and deleting key pairs
section.p: Use the Compute service to create a key pair, generate a new key pair using an existing pubkic key, and delete a key pair.

section.title: Tasks performed by an Administrator
section.p: The following Compute service tasks are usually performed by someone with the user role.

section.title: Creating, modifying and deleting flavors
section.p: Use the Compute service to create, delete, and modify the virtual machine flavors in a project. A flavor defines the hardware configuration (disk space and memory capacity).

section.title: Modifying project quotas
section.p: Use the Compute service to change the maximum limits on the number of objects (VMs, networks, and so on).

section.title: Creating, modifying, and deleting availability zones
section.p: Use the Compute service to manage availability zones (AZ) by creating and deleting AZs and modifying existing AZs.

section.title: Enabling and disabling services
section.p: Use the Compute service to enable or disable services available in a project.

section.title: Locking and unlocking a virtual machines
section.p: Use the Compute service to lock or unlock a virtual machine, as needed.

section.title: Pausing and un-pausing virtual machines
section.p: Use the Compute service to pause and un-pause a virtual machine.
The pause command stores the state of the VM in RAM. A paused instance continues to run in a frozen state.

section.title: Suspending and resuming virtual machines
section.p: Use the Compute service to suspend and un-suspend a virtual machine.

When you suspend an instance, its VM state is stored on disk, all memory is written to disk, and the virtual machine is stopped. Suspending an instance is similar to placing a device in hibernation; memory and vCPUs become available.

section.title: For more information
section.p: For information on how to operate your cloud we suggest you read the OpenStack Operations Guide The Architecture section contains useful information about how an OpenStack Cloud is put together. However, the HPE Helion OpenStack Community edition takes care of these details for you. The Operations contains information on how to manage the system.
